post.message: Other types of models (e.g. pole, zero model) are possibly more sensitive to perturbations.  For example, if we perturb the frequency information a little bit, the behaviour may not change much.  On the other hand, if we perturb the pole or zero a little bit, the behaviour can change dramatically.

post.subject: Re: Nyquist plot questions
post.message: If 1 zero of the characteristic equation is on the unit circle, then it is marginally stable. However, if more than 1 zero of the characteristic equation is on the unit circle, it is unstable.

post.subject: Re: Nyquist plot questions
post.message: Many approximations are made while arriving at the transfer function of any plant.  These approximations could have a bearing on the performance of the control system and in fact, the stability itself.  One way to account for these is through gain and phase margins.  We insist that these should be large enough to account for plant variations.  We refer to this as the unmodelled gains and delays.

post.subject: Re: Nyquist plot questions
post.message:
1. Open loop gain refers to the gain of the plant alone - this is $$G(z)$$ - this is the methodology I follow - this is what we will use in this course.  If the control system with a transfer function $$G_c(z)$$ is already present, some also refer to $$G(z)G_c(z)$$ as the open loop gain - but I will not use this nomenclature.  To arrive at the closed loop gain, one has to close the feedback loop first.  The closed loop gain is the transfer function between the external input (say, reference or disturbance signals) and the output of the plant.  It is of the form $$\dfrac{G_c(z)G(z)}{1+G_c(z)G(z)}$$.

2.  Using Nyquist plot, it is easier to explain the stability of systems, compared to Bode plots.  Nyquist and Bode plots can be built using experimental data alone - this cannot be done in other methods, for example, root-locus method, which relies on pole-zero information, which in turn is not available through experimentation.

post.subject: Re: Nyquist plot questions
post.message:
The directions of C1 and C3 have to be consistent, that's all.  If C1 is measured in the clockwise direction, you should count C2 (and hence, C3 and C4) also in the clockwise direction.  You may also use counterclockwise measurement.

There is only a sign change between the two.

post.subject: Re: Nyquist plot questions
post.message:
At infinity, we may have zeros, but not poles.  Only when the numerator transfer function is of greater degree than the denominator, we will have this situtaiton.  We know that this cannot happen for causal systems.  We will not deal with anything other than causal plants!

Because of this observation, we will never have to worry about unstable poles at infinity.

post.subject: Re: Nyquist plot questions
post.message: It is assumed that the degree of b(z) is less than that of a(z) and say a(z) is a polynomial in z of degree n. Then, 1+K*b(z)/a(z) = {a(z)+K*b(z)}/a(z). Now both the degrees of the polynomial in denominator and numerator is n. Hence the expression has n zeros( zeros of numerator) and n poles(zeros of denominator).
